response: "{ \"title\": \"Easy: Array Shift\", \"description\": \"Write a function that shifts the elements of an array to the right by a given number of positions. The function should handle arrays of any size and return the original array if the shift amount is 0.\\n\\n#### Function Signature\\n```python\\ndef shift_array(arr: list, shift: int) -> list:\\n```\\n\\n#### Input\\n- `arr` (list): A list of integers or strings that represents the array to be shifted.\\n- `shift` (int): The number of positions to shift the elements of the array to the right. Can be positive or negative.\\n\\n#### Output\\n- Returns the original array after applying the right shift operation.\\n\", \"code\": \"def shift_array(arr: list, shift: int) -> list:\\n    if shift == 0:\\n        return arr.copy()\\n    elif shift > 0:\\n        return arr[-shift:] + arr[:-shift]\\n    else:\\n        return [arr[i] for i in range(shift, len(arr))] + arr[:shift]\\n\", \"tests\": [\"assert shift_array([1, 2, 3], 1) == [3, 1, 2]\", \"assert shift_array(['a', 'b', 'c'], -2) == ['c', 'a', 'b']\", \"assert shift_array([1, 2, 3], 0) == [1, 2, 3]\", \"assert shift_array([], 1) == []\"] }"
